Nemuro Hanamaru Ginza Review | Bon Appetit









































Close Menu IconLoginRecipesCookingCultureShoppingRestaurantsBA MarketVideosPodcastSubscribe to our newsletterSign UpPrivacy and user agreementMain Navigation IconBA LogoBon appetitLogintokyoNemuro Hanamaru GinzaThe sushi conveyor belt you‘ve been dreaming of.FacebookPinterestTwitterEmailPhoto by Xavier Girard LachaîneGO HERE: to eat your weight in raw fish and rice without having to put up your arm and leg as collateral. Sushi has become such a highly sought-after commodity in Tokyo that both prices and wait times have ballooned to unreasonable levels. A $300 omakase dinner is already a stressful choice to make—and that’s not taking into account that reservation lists are often as long as a year or more. Nemuro Hanamaru does not require such extremes of its customers, and it also has something that haughty restaurants do not: fun. Just show up, get in line, and wait for your turn to start pulling as many plates as you can off the conveyor belt that circles the room. Watching your personal pile of empties stack up in front of you is a game unto itself.ORDER THE: items you definitely want by writing them on the provided order sheet and giving it to the waitress. But keep your eyes on the belt for specials you’ve never tried before.THE VIBE IS: a blend of the everyman culture of the restaurant and the glitz of the Ginza district bustling six floors below. Service is boisterous and efficient while  the sleek decor and views of the city outside can make the affordability of the food hard to believe. But don’t spend too much time staring out the window or the fish you really wanted might pass you by.PRACTICAL STUFF: Open daily from 11 a.m. to 11 p.m. An English menu is available and the staff speaks some English. The nearest subway station is Sapporo.Photo by Xavier Girard LachaîneNemuro Hanamaura has what‘s missing from so many other sushi restaurants: fun.
Photo by Xavier Girard LachaîneAs you pull from the conveyor belt, you‘ll watch the plates pile up in front of you.
